newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: STAD R'DAM AIMS TO INCREASE LIFE BUSINESS.
newsitem.headline: STAD R'DAM AIMS TO INCREASE LIFE BUSINESS.

text.p: Stad Rotterdam anno 1720 NV, ranked sixth largest among Dutch insurers, said on Wednesday it was aiming to increase its portfolio in life business compared to non-life.
"Some 70 percent of premium income from life business would be ideal," chairman Carlo de Swart said in an interview, noting that currently about 52 percent of premium income comes from life.
Stad Rotterdam said it expected premium income of its life business to increase to 1.6 billion guilders in 1996 from 1.5 billion guilders in the previous year.
Premium income from non-life was seen rising to 1.5 billion guilders in 1996 from 1.4 billion in 1995.
Stad Rotterdam said it based the 1996 estimates on its nine-months results, which were published on November 14.
De Swart said it would remain focussed on accident and health, despite its increasing attention to life business.
"Premium income in accident and health has been growing like mad," he said.
De Swart said the aim was to increase business especially in unit-linked products and individual pension schemes. "Life business is in any case a good field to be in," he said.
De Swart said unit-linked products had proven to be very profitable.
The chairman said it would put less emphasis on motor insurance as this business had been very cyclical.
Earlier he said the company was expecting a moderate profit in motor insurance in 1996, after announcing losses in the last few years.
De Swart said it had increased its technical reserves for motor insurance. "This used to be 48 percent of premium income, but we increased this to between 90-100 percent," De Swart said.
Premium-income on motor insurance was expected to have increased to 380-400 million guilders in 1996 from 363.1 million in 1995.
